meta.title: Sacred Grounds - The Supernal Gardens
meta.subtitle: Immersive convention marketing through environmental storytelling
meta.teaser: Designed and directed a live immersive marketing experience at a convention, combining environmental storytelling, actor-driven narrative, and tech-enhanced interactions to convert attendees into paying customers for future events.

project.summary: The Supernal Gardens was a free immersive marketing experience at a gaming convention, designed to showcase Sacred Grounds Gaming's live event format and convert attendees into future paying customers. I designed the narrative guest journey, wrote environmental storytelling elements, created actor character guides, and directed the experience on-site. The result was a 40% increase in attendance at the following paid Sacred Grounds event.

section.heading: The Challenge
section.body:
Sacred Grounds Gaming needed to market their monthly live game experiences at a convention. The challenge: transform a hotel convention hall into a fully immersive experience—complete with props, actors, and a story participants could actively impact—that would funnel attendees into future paid events.

Core Constraints

  • Audience: Attendees unfamiliar with immersive events need clear hooks to understand what to do
  • Varied engagement: Some would dive deep, others would casually browse
  • Clear conversion goal: Sign-ups for future paid Sacred Grounds events
  • Must emulate the product: The convention experience needed to feel like a preview of what they'd pay for

section.heading: The Approach: Participant-Driven Narrative
section.body:
Rather than a passive booth or static display, I designed the experience so that participants would immediately become part of the story. The key insight: participants are special.

Prophetic Powers

Participants' devices give them abilities the actors don't have—scanning QR codes reveals hidden information, and RFID-tagged items unlock video prophecies at the scrying pool.

Story Conforms to Actions

How much participants investigate and reveal shapes the narrative. The story adapts to their level of engagement—passive observers get a show, active investigators uncover conspiracies.

Actor Autonomy

Every actor has a backstory, motivation, and personal goals. They don't follow scripts—they improv while pursuing their character's objectives, creating authentic interactions.

This approach directly mirrors how normal Sacred Grounds events work, so the convention experience is the product demo.

section.heading: The Guest Journey
section.body:
Registration & Onboarding

Guests could pre-register through convention sign-ups or walk in. The event was free, but participants signed a waiver and provided contact info (the first conversion point). Content warnings covered violence, prop blood, and swearing, with age restrictions for certain activities.

A brief onboarding session explained how to interact with actors, scan QR codes, and use tagged props—with example interactions to loosen people up and set expectations.

Narrative Setup

"You are colonists aboard the GTS Mercurious, crewed by reformed pirates. You were en route to settle the Isle of Lucania when an unexpected storm forced you to dock at the Isle of Casoria instead. The people here are strange, and the local Magistrate is even stranger—and possibly dangerous. Find out what you can about the locals, and keep Captain Tallhorn safe."

— First Mate Zala Bag-o-bones

The Inciting Incident

As participants entered the main hall, the Magistrate rose from his marble throne to welcome them to the Supernal Gardens—pointing out activities and places to explore, the picture of a gracious host.

Then the mood shifted. He called out two fighters for his local tournament. One nearly killed the other.

Participants could stay and watch, or begin exploring. Actors were specifically on the lookout for aimless participants, redirecting them through conversation and suggestions.

Rising Action & Discovery

Through interactions with actors, finding tagged objects, timed story events, and scanning QR codes, participants could uncover the truth:

  • The storm was fabricated by witches
  • The Magistrate intends to keep the colonists here to participate in his games
  • Various characters have their own agendas that participants can help or hinder

Multiple Endings

Participants could decide how to resolve the story:

  • Plot an escape with the crew
  • Turn the Magistrate in to the local senate using gathered evidence
  • Something unexpected—actors were trained to improvise for creative participants

section.heading: The Experience Stations
section.body: The overall format was a highly interactive murder mystery party, with distinct zones serving different narrative and engagement purposes.

section.heading: The Arena
section.body:
Main Gathering Area

The Arena served as the story progression hub. The Magistrate hosted a gladiator tournament honoring the "unexpected guests," with the ship's Captain invited to participate.

  • Key cast members lingered here when big plot moments were about to happen
  • Participants could watch the story unfold, talk with actors, or influence outcomes
  • Each cast character had a backstory, motivation, and personal goals participants could discover by asking the right questions

section.heading: The Bar
section.body:
Social Hub & Information Exchange

The Bar showcased our strongest acting talent and served as the primary social/information hub.

Sample Interactions

  • The Bartender: Trades valuable information for a good joke
  • A Nervous Senator: Terrified his wife will find him here—pays gold coins to be escorted out unseen
  • Close-up card tricks: Wager gold coins against skilled performers
  • Information extraction: Use charisma or blackmail to pry secrets from knowledgeable characters

Tech Integration: Prophetic Visions

Participants have prophetic powers in the story world, and their devices are the conduit. QR codes on items reveal hidden information invisible to the actors.

Example: The Pirate's Stein

Scanning the QR code on a pirate's drinking vessel reveals: "You see a vision of death—there's poison in this drink!" Can you stop him from chugging a lethal dose?

section.heading: The Scrying Pool
section.body:
Mystical Discovery Zone

A mystical fountain with a hidden RFID scanner. Participants could find or trade for items with visible RFID tags—the signal that an item was "scryable."

Bringing a tagged item to the pool triggered a video prophecy related to that item, revealing key plot information. Through the scrying pool, participants could learn the Magistrate's true intentions and discover how to safely expose him.

section.heading: The Joust
section.body:
Competition Zone

Carnival-style games and yard games, each with their own story context. Participating and winning resulted in rewards: gold coins, items, or information that could be used elsewhere in the experience.

section.heading: Environmental Storytelling Systems
section.body:
To enable actor autonomy and consistent participant experiences, I developed several systems and artifacts.

Cast Member Cards

Each actor received a character card with everything they needed to improv effectively. Actors were organized into three tiers based on their narrative function:

Actor Role Tiers

  • Major Roles: Directly linked to the main narrative. Interactions with these characters could unlock scrying pool items or impact the story's outcome.
  • Minor Roles: Interactive side stories that connected to Major Roles. They provided context, quests, and pathways to deeper engagement.
  • Enhancement Roles: Atmosphere and guidance. Pre-briefed on all narrative threads, they functioned as "narrative customer service"—spotting lost participants and directing them toward content.

How the Tiers Worked Together

An Enhancement Role actor notices someone standing around, seemingly unsure of what to do. They strike up a conversation to find out what the participant might be interested in, then point them toward an activity or someone in a Minor Role: "I hear the barmaid is looking to buy an herbal remedy and willing to pay a lot for it. You can talk to her to find out more."

The participant approaches the barmaid (Minor Role). Her husband is sick at home and needs herbal remedies. After talking with her, the participant is pointed to Tansy Greenwillow (Major Role). Interaction with Tansy can result in scrying pool items or directly impacting the narrative.

Example Character Cards

Mira "Saltblood" Vance

Faction: Crew (GTS Mercurious)

Backstory: Former naval officer turned privateer after her fleet was destroyed by the Magistrate's "games" five years ago. She joined the Mercurious to start fresh, but recognizes the Isle of Casoria—she's been here before, and barely escaped.

Magistrate stance: Knows he's dangerous, suspects he's behind their "accidental" arrival

Demeanor: Guarded, observant, speaks in low tones

Motivation: Protect the crew and escape before history repeats itself

Goals:

  • Find proof the storm was manufactured
  • Identify which locals might help them escape
  • Keep an eye on anyone getting too close to Captain Tallhorn

Dominus Kael

Faction: Magistrate Loyalist

Backstory: The Magistrate's Guard Captain. Rose from poverty through the arena—the Magistrate "saved" him by making him a champion, then a soldier. He owes everything to the Magistrate and enforces his will without question. Almost.

Magistrate stance: Publicly devoted. Privately, haunted by what he's done.

Demeanor: Intimidating, terse, avoids eye contact

Motivation: Maintain order and protect his position

Goals:

  • Ensure no colonist causes trouble
  • Report suspicious behavior to the Magistrate
  • (Secret) Avoid confronting the guilt of past actions

Tansy Greenwillow

Faction: Witch (Secret)

Backstory: Poses as a simple herbalist selling remedies at the bar. Actually one of the witches who conjured the storm. She's having second thoughts—the Magistrate promised no one would get hurt, but the arena fights are getting bloodier.

Magistrate stance: Fears him. Regrets helping him. Looking for a way out.

Demeanor: Friendly, chatty, nervously changes subject when magic is mentioned

Motivation: Undo her mistake without getting caught

Goals:

  • Sell herbal remedies for gold coins (repeatable)
  • Find someone trustworthy to reveal the truth to
  • Avoid the other witches who remain loyal to the Magistrate

Items: RFID-tagged "Storm Charm" (reveals witch conspiracy at scrying pool)

section.heading: Scrying Pool Scripts
section.body:
RFID-tagged items triggered specific video prophecies at the scrying pool. Here are two examples:

Prophecy: The Storm Charm

Triggered by: RFID-tagged charm from Tansy Greenwillow

"The waters cloud... and clear to show three figures on a cliff, hands raised to blackened skies. Lightning dances at their command. Below, a ship struggles against waves that should not exist.

One figure turns—you see her face. You've seen her before. At the bar. Selling herbs.

The storm is not natural. The storm is a cage. And the cage was built for you."

Participant takeaway: The storm was manufactured by witches. The herbalist Tansy is involved. This information can be used to confront her or trade with other characters.

Prophecy: The Guard Captain's Medal

Triggered by: RFID-tagged medal from Dominus Kael

"The waters cloud... and clear to show a younger man, bloodied, standing over a fallen opponent in the arena. The crowd roars. The Magistrate descends to place this very medal around his neck.

The vision shifts. Night. The same man, now in guard's armor, dragging a hooded figure through the gardens. The figure struggles. A muffled scream. Then silence.

The vision shifts again. The guard captain, alone, staring at the medal in his hands. His shoulders shake. He's weeping.

He remembers what he did. He carries it with him. Always."

Participant takeaway: The Guard Captain has committed crimes for the Magistrate and is haunted by guilt. This information could be used as blackmail to turn him against the Magistrate—or to show him compassion and earn an ally.

section.heading: The Funnel: Discovery to Conversion
section.body:
Every element of the experience was designed to serve the business goal: converting convention attendees into paying customers for future Sacred Grounds events.

The Conversion Funnel

1. Discovery
Convention floor presence, visual hook, pre-registration option, marketing emails, convention program listing
2. Data Capture
Free entry, but waiver + contact info required
3. Emotional Investment
Immersive experience creates connection to the brand and format
4. Tangible Hook
Gold coins earned in-experience are redeemable at real Sacred Grounds events (free first event, bonus items)
5. Exit Conversion
Three sign-up stations on the way out: next event registration, email newsletter, social follows. Goody bag with marketing materials.

A post-mortem session explained the full experience for those interested, revealing how everything connected and answering questions about what they'd discovered—or missed.

section.heading: Results
section.body:
40%

Attendance increase at the following Sacred Grounds event

The convention experience demonstrated that participants would engage deeply with narrative-driven immersive events—and that giving them agency over the story created emotional investment that translated into conversion.

Key Takeaways

  • The product is the demo: By making the convention experience a microcosm of paid events, we let the format sell itself
  • Participant powers work: Tech-enhanced interactions (QR, RFID) created moments of discovery that felt magical
  • Actor autonomy scales: Character cards enabled consistent, engaging improv without rigid scripts
  • Multiple engagement levels: Casual observers and dedicated investigators both had meaningful experiences
